section.title: Troubleshooting
section.para: As you work with CentOS Studio to create deployment templates and config-rpms, you will occasionally run into errors. When these occur, CentOS Studio halts operation and displays error information to the console. It also records error messages in the CentOS Studio log file, by default /var/log/centosstudio.log.

In addition to displaying and logging error messages, CentOS Studio provides assistance for troubleshooting errors that occur during client-side script processing. Client-side scripts include some deployment scripts and config-rpm scripts and triggers.

section.title: Troubleshooting errors in client-side deployment scripts
section.para: When CentOS Studio executes a deployment script using SSH, it first copies the script to the client machine and then executes it from there. To assist with troubleshooting, CentOS Studio leaves copied scripts on the client machine. They can be located in the folder at /var/lib/centosstudio/deploy.

Each script exists in a separate file, with a filename corresponding to the script's @id attribute. By executing the script from command line on the client machine, you will be able to reproduce and troubleshoot errors. To execute the script from the command line, type ./script_name at a command prompt.
section.note: You can view virtual clients created by the virt-deploy template by typing virt-manager at the command line of the CentOS Studio build machine.

section.title: Troubleshooting errors in config-rpm scripts
section.para: In addition, CentOS Studio saves copies of config-rpm scripts on client machines. These can be located in the /var/lib/centosstudio/config folder, in subfolders by RPM ID, e.g. httpd-config. Within the RPM ID subfolder, files are named by script type, e.g. post-script and postun-script. Trigger scripts are named by trigger type, followed by the name of the trigger, e.g. triggerin-drupal-script.

Config-rpm script errors will typically be reported within the context of either the verify-install or the update deployment scripts. From the error messages, you can determine the package in which the script error occured.

Errors in trigger scripts can be more difficult to troubleshoot. You will need to search folders in the /var/lib/centosstudio/config folder to locate which config-rpm, if any, provided the errant trigger script.
Once you have located the error-producing script, you can execute it from the command line by typing ./script_name. This will allow you to reproduce and troubleshoot the error.
